awd_abstract_narration:
Private archaeological collections are abundant in the United States, holding upwards of 90% of informative artifacts like "arrow points."  The full story of how prehistoric cultures coped with adversity and environmental change demands incorporating into archaeological research the knowledge that resides in private collections.  The Central Ohio Archaeological Digitization Survey (COADS) is the first systematic effort to map and digitize collections from a specific region of the United States, the remarkable prehistoric landscape of Ohio's central Scioto Valley.  One of its chief innovations is to treat local knowledge as integral to the archaeological record and research.  In the process, COADS documents prehistoric cultural transitions as responses to population growth, economic change, and landscape development. It uses archaeology's unique perspective to study tempo and mode of long-term technological change. COADS serves as a model for engaging the public in contributing to understanding of the human condition, and improves understanding of how prehistoric native cultures thrived over long periods. COADS also provides students and involved citizens training in proper mapping and documentation methods, and expands data-collection for preservation planning.  COADS facilitates efficient and responsible stewardship of heritage resources, and planning more efficiently for development that capitalizes on heritage while maximizing preservation. Finally, COADS creates an enormous database of virtual collections that can be used for research and education purposes long after the physical material is dispersed.

COADS integrates the materials from private collections with previous site- and region-based analyses into a composite model of distribution of human activity on the landscape over time. Previous work constructed a mutually reinforcing model of transition from mobility to residential stability (i.e., more sedentary populations) concomitant with a shift to increasing focus on, and eventual domestication of, seed crops. COADS employs geometric morphometrics to explore: 1) the implications of sedentism through the predicted effects on tool shape and degree of toolstone curation; and 2) the nature of transition of technology from one "type" to another. COADS creates the biggest archive of private collections for a region. Through high resolution 3D and 2D scanning, COADS serves as a portable research and education resource for the public and scholars. Increasingly it is realized that prehistory is not accurately characterized by the major excavated sites. One must examine all parts of the landscape and multiple aspects of past cultural systems. Documenting private collections fills many of the gaps in the official record.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the Central Ohio Archaeological Digitization project (COADS) are to bring the public into the composition of the archaeological record. We recognize that the vast majority of sites and artifacts are in private hands and that these private collections are threatened. Once these collections are dispersed, their information is lost. COADS documented and analyzed over 17,000 artifacts from 32 collections, increasing the number of known diagnostic tools nearly 5 times for the region. COADS created a Python script tool to facilitate large-scale analysis of geographic patterns with a set of collected background layers to facilitate spatial analysis of land use through time This tool is publicly available and being incorporated into dozens of publications and reports annually. Students at Ball State helped design the tool, and use the tool in GIS research for a variety of publications which they coauthor with Applied Anthropology Laboratories (AAL) staff. Each publication contributes to the cumulative knowledge of the regional archaeology and builds robust records of professional and scholarly achievement for the students.

COADS is contributing to public engagement with archaeology and historic preservation through out publicly available digital resources. Our hundreds of 3D artifact models are used in dozens of public education and outreach events by AAL staff and student employees.  These outreach events engage hundreds of visitors annually, providing more direct access the raw (virtual) materials of regional archaeology.

The large samples of various artifact types spanning the entire span of Indigenous history in central Ohio is enabling new and highly detailed analysis of variation and change in technology and interaction with the environment. While only in the early stages, this analysis has identified interpretive and analytical errors in previous research with less sophisticated analytical methods and/or smaller samples. COADS methods, data, and findings have bearing on issues of the development of regionally distinct social identities hypothesized for various periods. Future products will expand this analysis to cover most of the range of Indigenous history in the COADS region.

Publicly available resources derived from COADS:

Central Ohio Archaeological Digitization Survey Collection of 3D Artifact Models: https://skfb.ly/6urqw

Generalized Chert Sources of Ohio, version 1.0: https://arcg.is/SryL8  

Anthropology Report Generator (ARG) Toolbox Package: https://arcg.is/14KCje0  

Central Ohio Archaeological Digitization Survey: Preliminary Report.  

Current Research in Ohio Archaeology 2021: https://www.ohioarchaeology.org/articles-and-abstracts-2021/601-central-ohio-archaeological-digitization-survey-preliminary-report

Publication available via the authors:

COADS: A Demonstration of Amplified Public Good from Collaboration with Private Collectors. In Advances in Archaeological Practice 10(1):83-90; special issue: Professional-Collector Collaboration: Moving Beyond Debate to Global Practice, edited by BL Pitblado, B Schroeder, S Thomas, and MJ Rowe. DOI: 10.1017/aap.2021.33: https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/advances-in-archaeological-practice/article/abs/central-ohio-archaeological-digitization-survey/D2E5CF61886608CBA54C31C86BE84EBE
